Comment: The dinosaurs, even down to the local county parties, have so much of their identity invested that they're clutching on for life. Sometimes the pendulum swings too hard when control is finally wrested, but then it's often "too far" for centrists and the party gets labeled extreme, regardless of our quest for normalcy and good. They should pass the baton and serve advisory roles only, allowing the meaty part of the bell curve to take over. This is the only way to intelligently utilize new skills of the young, while applying the wisdom of the old.

Comment: The current leadership thinks they can run the same tired playbook forever because no one inside the party has made them pay a price for it. Why pass the torch when the donor money keeps rolling in, the consultant class keeps winning, and the base is told over and over again that the stakes are too high to ask for better?  Schumer’s a perfect example of how deep that rot goes. He didn’t invent performative resistance, but he’s one of its most reliable players—loud when it’s safe, silent when it matters, always ready with a press release while real change gets sidelined. He isn’t going anywhere because people like him never plan to.       They turn these seats into personal property, coasting on gestures and slogans while the rest of us argue about whether demanding more is “helping the other side.”
Author: Kei_the_gamer

Comment: I don’t think they really understand how damaging this is to the Democratic Party and brand. The whole point of being the progressive party and forward looking is to…actually be progressive and forward looking.  The entire reason that Trump gained traction in the first place was “drain the swamp” as he pointed out the hypocrisy of multi millionaire congresspeople like Nanci Pelosi making bank off their long political careers at the expense of tax payers.  Everyone will say Trump is *more corrupt*. Democrats are held to a different standard because *it’s their standard*

Comment: It is time for us all to take a look at the bigger picture.  Set aside the emotions.  Yes he had a few votes lately that sucked.  We need to take a look at the whole, not just the most recent.  When older people dig in hard, especially when they know they likely will not get re-elected, something is going on. Something they can't let go of.  Something they feel they need to see through.  Did anybody bother to ask the man?  Anyone remember the Schumer Amendment on UAP?  of course not, Americans have the memory of a fruit fly. This man knows things. I think he is fighting for progress to avoid another 80 years of secret programs on the taxpayer dime. Trillions of dollars.    Instead of complaining like kindergarteners we need to start publicly asking very blunt questions.  What does he know that we aren't being told.  He needs to be asked loudly and publicly if he is attempting to stop billions of dollars from going into Musk's SpaceX.   Your money. To fund projects on Mars.
